document.title: Elementary Science, Intermediate Science, Living Environment, Earth Science, Chemistry, and Physics Core Curriculum

A0B7071CD2C7471BA38F02B753E3C20C.description: Solving interdisciplinary problems involves a variety of skills and strategies, including effective work habits; gathering and processing information; generating and analyzing ideas; realizing ideas; making connections among the common themes of mathematics, science, and technology; and presenting results.

D4B95CAFFCC24CADA5A0D31516872184.description: observe phenomena and evaluate them scientifically and mathematically by conducting a fair test of the effect of variables and using mathematical knowledge and technological tools to collect, analyze, and present data and conclusions

F6C7E8D6CCEC4C6CB6659FE361ABE5BB.description: design solutions to problems involving a familiar and real context, investigate related science concepts to inform the solution, and use mathematics to model, quantify, measure, and compute

FE504F5802B64635AA8BC36564272199.description: make informed consumer decisions by applying knowledge about the attributes of particular products and making cost/benefit tradeoffs to arrive at an optimal choice

181E16F372FC451B9E62D80DC02702B4.description: analyze science/technology/society problems and issues that affect their home, school, or community, and carry out a remedial course of action

CD95CF3487DC4D959682C1DA907E9A22.description: The knowledge and skills of mathematics, science, and technology are used together to make informed decisions and solve problems, especially those relating to issues of science/technology/society, consumer decision making, design, and inquiry into phenomena.

7D35DD42696A44489E4703BE4F536ED1.description: Students will apply the knowledge and thinking skills of mathematics, science, and technology to address real-life problems and make informed decisions.

D6877FAA15894F14959CA464EDBA8121.description: explain the criteria used in selecting a solution orally and in writing

5E6FADBE368C44C3997A236F2BF5BB61.description: choose the best alternative of a set of solutions under given constraints

44C4FA5C8933478B890CA908B30255FE.description: In order to arrive at the best solution that meets criteria within constraints, it is often necessary to make trade-offs.

D8604C979AE747AA885B7F0490024391.description: analyze data by making tables and graphs and looking for patterns of change

7823ECEBC0F24640BD6BA1E25493B7CA.description: use simple instruments to measure such quantities as distance, size, and weight and look for patterns in the data

86232DD5739E4EEB9664F248C64BDD9B.description: Identifying patterns of change is necessary for making predictions about future behavior and conditions

AD2AF92D23B741AEADF29DC7C2945696.description: recognize that things can change in different ways such as size, weight, color, and movement. Some small changes can be detected by taking measurements.

56A7ABA154074E7DA0B7DA7A01FC7F8A.description: observe that things change in some ways and stay the same in some ways

DF0587EBCF934ECD9FC07C6DAC4CEF3C.description: Equilibrium is a state of stability due either to a lack of changes (static equilibrium) or a balance between opposing forces (dynamic equilibrium).

45FED83ADAAD49D1862D86648652937D.description: recognize that almost anything has limits on how big or small it can be

50B32771498F46999D43458647D460AF.description: observe that things in nature and things that people make have very different sizes, weights, and ages

8532A9AA03074C3F93B54BBDAB4AE59D.description: The grouping of magnitudes of size, time, frequency, and pressures or other units of measurement into a series of relative order provides a useful way to deal with the immense range and the changes in scale that affect the behavior and design of systems

79D57BBB6C47443E987E06BA9CE16AE5.description: use different types of models, such as graphs, sketches, diagrams, and maps, to represent various aspects of the real world

B01C28FD85C64B9595170B17AD0C3106.description: discover that a model of something is different from the real thing but can be used to study the real thing

92AC25E5FFF84FCAB12405E63526A36F.description: analyze, construct, and operate models in order to discover attributes of the real thing

264CDE130510424A9DED3A3750B3FAF7.description: Models are simplified representations of objects, structures, or systems used in analysis, explanation, interpretation, or design.

9EB8E593525645CEA23DF43B8FAF4B9A.description: identify common things that can be considered to be systems (e.g., a plant population, a subway system, human beings)

48572D352FB74614ADEF4CC6720B247F.description: observe and describe interactions among components of simple systems

6FE8984AD4664C1D99A823BDF8515FF2.description: Through systems thinking, people can recognize the commonalities that exist among all systems and how parts of a system interrelate and combine to perform specific functions.

E9BDAD1279054F58A0803136CA2D8B11.description: Students will understand the relationships and common themes that connect mathematics, science, and technology and apply the themes to these and other areas of learning.

79ACFC3CA25644DEA0EF644E14627CEA.description: Humans, as individuals or communities, change environments in ways that can be either helpful or harmful for themselves and other organisms.

0A649F717654404F8AF16BE1C53FDA89.description: Over time humans have changed their environment by cultivating crops and raising animals, creating shelter, using energy, manufacturing goods, developing means of transportation, changing populations, and carrying out other activities.

C81D97DD0E2448EF922D1D4EBC56B7CA.description: Humans depend on their natural and constructed environments.

AED5D3022B5342DFB46FB6FBABFD80AC.description: Identify ways in which humans have changed their environment and the effects of those changes

DDB723FCB9EA4103B032EC837A70FB2B.description: Human decisions and activities have had a profound impact on the physical and living environment.

3E24139F101A4F728EFE45B33C6D6107.description: Heat energy from the Sun powers the water cycle (see Physical Science Key Idea 2).

7AFE5F12EB734991908F693F499AF943.description: The Sun's energy is transferred on Earth from plants to animals through the food chain.

26353CBCAD4A4855970BB32C6FB54F6E.description: Plants manufacture food by utilizing air, water, and energy from the Sun.

D98AF7F29F314C7B81BD383B630ACE5B.description: Describe the relationship of the sun as an energy source for living and nonliving cycles

1661ED4BAB1A4026890935C1837F12FA.description: When the environment changes, some plants and animals survive and reproduce, and others die or move to new locations.

F1F8FAE4D0724CA38F86AA95432AB3ED.description: An organism's pattern of behavior is related to the nature of that organism's environment, including the kinds and numbers of other organisms present, the availability of food and other resources, and the physical characteristics of the environment.

CECBE17BE1FD4017B234AC47FBE356A2.description: Decomposers are living things that play a vital role in recycling nutrients.

A5525F45FC414B42A7D2B4B715EA97AF.description: Animals that eat plants for food may in turn become food for other animals. This sequence is called a food chain.

EC570D196DFF4B1AA2A69FD410EAA8ED.description: All animals depend on plants. Some animals (predators) eat other animals (prey).

E7E2E7DE6AAD4372B4C2B942E42ED6EF.description: Green plants are producers because they provide the basic food supply for themselves and animals.

F4AF1460BB5740F6A076F76455FAD7E8.description: Describe how plants and animals, including humans, depend upon each other and the nonliving environment

EB977AD8B02A4378AF068FE5258ECD37.description: Plants and animals depend on each other and their physical environment.

78B1C081BA3A42698E006C1F1E088B9B.description: Good health habits include hand washing and personal cleanliness; avoiding harmful substances (including alcohol, tobacco, illicit drugs); eating a balanced diet; engaging in regular exercise.

8E04393BE68E4E8ABC2F5F40B303C1F5.description: Humans need a variety of healthy foods, exercise, and rest in order to grow and maintain good health.

4929CB5577CF47C1ABE8A54E25861856.description: Describe the factors that help promote good health and growth in humans

DD31029448394D10B6178C47CAB24344.description: The health, growth, and development of organisms are affected by environmental conditions such as the availability of food, air, water, space, shelter, heat, and sunlight.

FEEDE3F7E4BF425D94CD7CA448CB2C25.description: Some animal behaviors are influenced by environmental conditions. These behaviors may include: nest building, hibernating, hunting, migrating, and communicating.

477795B393564E65A811585FB8CB86D5.description: Particular animal characteristics are influenced by changing environmental conditions including: fat storage in winter, coat thickness in winter, camouflage, shedding of fur.

E2E1E4334B524A62AB5B1BECB9AA5704.description: Some animals, including humans, move from place to place to meet their needs.

8895E5637EB24EFBB38CDA0BD558CC15.description: Senses can provide essential information (regarding danger, food, mates, etc.) to animals about their environment.

76C3693F29FB43BDB6C04594BB1A0455.description: Animals respond to change in their environment, (e.g., perspiration, heart rate, breathing rate, eye blinking, shivering, and salivating).

113A4366472447EF9CEC66DD55BACA2D.description: Plants respond to changes in their environment. For example, the leaves of some green plants change position as the direction of light changes; the parts of some plants undergo seasonal changes that enable the plant to grow; seeds germinate, and leaves form and grow.

47D0C6558CC9444BAC70BE0557406DC7.description: Describe some survival behaviors of common living specimens

AF321B1A772D4C05AB126A347856C22A.description: An organism's external physical features can enable it to carry out life functions in its particular environment.

1A8B3D016AEF4F35AE7480A05D9EEECE.description: All living things grow, take in nutrients, breathe, reproduce, and eliminate waste.

1CC83A6BC48746838BB3ADAEB6DC944C.description: Describe basic life functions of common living specimens (guppy, mealworm, gerbil)

1D5E2863DDC94A69BBBBCADB616815B7.description: Organisms maintain a dynamic equilibrium that sustains life.

02D9971C7A774F5A9B94C83A967E0959.description: Food supplies the energy and materials necessary for growth and repair.

F2C43296A2AD4487A743CD1740E97A80.description: Growth is the process by which plants and animals increase in size.

23BA67F1DEE44EDEA03CDB6238A761E8.description: Describe evidence of growth, repair, and maintenance, such as nails, hair, and bone, and the healing of cuts and bruises

D35E395B1D024A85AC82BD99A70D6C60.description: The length of time from an animal's birth to its death is called its life span. Life spans of different animals vary.

F54F985656B841B9AECE3CBF718E7E1B.description: Each kind of animal goes through its own stages of growth and development during its life span.

396081B707784A9D861DD25426C48277.description: Each generation of animals goes through changes in form from young to adult. This completed sequence of changes in form is called a life cycle. Some insects change from egg to larva to pupa to adult.

696E8C92E456488DBB372EC9AB6D38CC.description: Life cycles of some plants include changes from seed to mature plant.

807BA81063B44589B1F55F17B5C1A1D6.description: The length of time from beginning of development to death of the plant is called its life span.

5689438586464616A41226D93FC20D7C.description: Each kind of plant goes through its own stages of growth and development that may include seed, young plant, and mature plant.

4D409846BE4D4236B0D7700AD2ABE938.description: Plants and animals have life cycles. These may include beginning of a life, development into an adult, reproduction as an adult, and eventually death.

E9240498260247ED909A14634774D74C.description: Describe the major stages in the life cycles of selected plants and animals

4A16E7E3FA384F4FA83BB51626966833.description: The continuity of life is sustained through reproduction and development.

341538C0B00548679EE08B1FCDA9573F.description: All individuals have variations, and because of these variations, individuals of a species may have an advantage in surviving and reproducing.

03AFB6A9F06B4EFA8CFAF2DF21A10433.description: Individuals within a species may compete with each other for food, mates, space, water, and shelter in their environment.

CF745566D7454CB9BAADB13E7BDD0F93.description: Observe that differences within a species may give individuals an advantage in surviving and reproducing

FFCFB0E9415944CFA056E4748CD6CF2D.description:
In order to survive in their environment, plants and animals must be adapted to that environment.
  • seeds disperse by a plant's own mechanism and/or in a variety of ways that can include wind, water, and animals
  • leaf, flower, stem, and root adaptations may include variations in size, shape, thickness, color, smell, and texture
  • animal adaptations include coloration for warning or attraction, camouflage, defense mechanisms, movement, hibernation, and migration

124D29BD3DDE4C6A97FB101FC3359ED9.description:
Each plant has different structures that serve different functions in growth, survival, and reproduction.
  • roots help support the plant and take in water and nutrients
  • leaves help plants utilize sunlight to make food for the plant
  • stems, stalks, trunks, and other similar structures provide support for the plant
  • some plants have flowers
  • flowers are reproductive structures of plants that produce fruit which contains seeds
  • seeds contain stored food that aids in germination and the growth of young plants

5CFC272F08154CFAB45D3AAEB81ED977.description:
Each animal has different structures that serve different functions in growth, survival, and reproduction.
  • wings, legs, or fins enable some animals to seek shelter and escape predators
  • the mouth, including teeth, jaws, and tongue, enables some animals to eat and drink
  • eyes, nose, ears, tongue, and skin of some animals enable the animals to sense their surroundings
  • claws, shells, spines, feathers, fur, scales, and color of body covering enable some animals to protect themselves from predators and other environmental conditions, or enable them to obtain food
  • some animals have parts that are used to produce sounds and smells to help the animal meet its needs
  • the characteristics of some animals change as seasonal conditions change (e.g., fur grows and is shed to help regulate body heat; body fat is a form of stored energy and it changes as the seasons change)

8ACBB5ED0C224DB69B8BB514FF12BCF0.description: Describe how the structures of plants and animals complement the environment of the plant or animal

2D88F0F7ABB24A8198E1DC1D18A970F9.description: Individual organisms and species change over time.

8FCDFAC2F76C48AAA8CCA1B835EFFCD1.description: Plants and animals can transfer specific traits to their offspring when they reproduce.

BAED4A2F9BE5499493086CAF5B55EEA3.description: Plants and animals closely resemble their parents and other individuals in their species.

DB14699B667E4806A4C42520E42A55E9.description: Recognize that for humans and other living things there is genetic continuity between generations

974C7DD158A54729BF1C2FD61E62B20E.description: Some characteristics result from an individual's interactions with the environment and cannot be inherited by the next generation (e.g., having scars; riding a bicycle).

166DD9DC0EB7478992031519CFB6FF08.description: Some traits of living things have been inherited (e.g., color of flowers and number of limbs of animals).

7389DE1735D24979A6A3D33C68F75A01.description: Recognize that traits of living things are both inherited and acquired or learned

DAFD9E34FB8A4DD5B08356C3F9C83EA0.description: Organisms inherit genetic information in a variety of ways that result in continuity of structure and function between parents and offspring.

6206F0027F8A4FA7ACEBC3D205430E1C.description: Living things grow, take in nutrients, breathe, reproduce, eliminate waste, and die.

6D127259093843EE973844C043F08B57.description: Describe the life processes common to all living things

B0C478B81A954FFE843F6F1513CAF5DF.description: Nonliving things can be human-created or naturally occurring.

14C9F68712024E59AFC0BE799A148F13.description: Nonliving things do not live and thrive.

60B5BB13458F4E39B35AB80D99F68937.description: Plants require air, water, nutrients, and light in order to live and thrive.

51572F51799B4EA5ACD38D2A5D8914E5.description: Animals need air, water, and food in order to live and thrive.

C05C6105EA9C4EA6AE38539267BB58ED.description: Describe the characteristics of and variations between living and nonliving things

30A8C059732142A181DA357DA39ED2D3.description: Living things are both similar to and different from each other and nonliving things.

67E903E78B794A768A87C6F0938EA865.description: The force of magnetism on objects decreases as distance increases.

85596FEFA96E4BE19424C52E13FAEAA2.description: The forces of gravity and magnetism can affect objects through gases, liquids, and solids.

4C5353EEE2104B5CBC1A3F60E6A696A4.description: Describe how forces can operate across distances

8A71E30F479247C1858E84A5F3D628C8.description: Mechanical energy may cause change in motion through the application of force and through the use of simple machines such as pulleys, levers, and inclined planes.

7E0082B952554B4A8980B124B454E38D.description: Magnetism is a force that may attract or repel certain materials.

E8661B5078A34B2291BF8DB5880C297A.description: The amount of change in the motion of an object is affected by friction.

4AB669532D2D4E05B1046B8F5B03288A.description: The force of gravity pulls objects toward the center of Earth.

2CCC255A6A0049B48CE7A8FB9DAAFB03.description: The position or direction of motion of an object can be changed by pushing or pulling.

079525721F7C49BDB0DC8536F1770072.description: The position of an object can be described by locating it relative to another object or the background (e.g., on top of, next to, over, under, etc.).

5CEABE5A0035492491C5105A088C1965.description: Describe the effects of common forces (pushes and pulls) on objects, such as those caused by gravity, magnetism, and mechanical forces

E59721080BE24052BC28BEE2AC78FB48.description: Energy and matter interact through forces that result in changes in motion.

DEFC8595AB8B41D0878C39AC8710B6E4.description:
Humans utilize interactions between matter and energy.
  • chemical to electrical, light, and heat: battery and bulb
  • electrical to sound (e.g., doorbell buzzer)
  • mechanical to sound (e.g., musical instruments, clapping)
  • light to electrical (e.g., solar-powered calculator)

85F1E2EB2F674DF0A03239225C70B3AF.description:
Everyday events involve one form of energy being changed to another.
  • animals convert food to heat and motion
  • the Sun's energy warms the air and water

DA25DFC721124C658E60D9D7B68769C2.description: Observe the way one form of energy can be transformed into another form of energy present in common situations (e.g., mechanical to heat energy, mechanical to electrical energy, chemical to heat energy)

3E99890BA58142F6B72CEC345ADA05F1.description: Interactions with forms of energy can be either helpful or harmful.

F0D2B19671D64DFFAB616C3E93863FC6.description: Heat can be released in many ways, for example, by burning, rubbing (friction), or combining one substance with another.

AE89A738F2694979BF9AD595501D7AE9.description: Electricity travels in a closed circuit.

70E1B1693DF94FCCAC1CBF13A211ABD4.description: Energy and matter interact: water is evaporated by the Sun's heat; a bulb is lighted by means of electrical current; a musical instrument is played to produce sound; dark colors may absorb light, light colors may reflect light.

43A2B88FAFE84E09A1A02E1521A4935B.description: Some materials transfer energy better than others (heat and electricity).

FB8D18388BB74982895A620D6F0AE3AB.description: Energy can be transferred from one place to another.

1B4292D17E6646269AE8C919891CB06E.description: Energy exists in various forms: heat, electric, sound, chemical, mechanical, light.

B43ED9BD8BA04E2EA9DD462E3F1356C6.description: Describe a variety of forms of energy (e.g., heat, chemical, light) and the changes that occur in objects when they interact with those forms of energy

7F418A61265741F59CF4D3125FA60899.description: Energy exists in many forms, and when these forms change energy is conserved.

320210B1C22445A19A888DFD93AF8312.description: Changes in the properties or materials of objects can be observed and described.

C780AD2DE93C4CD5AA5437024E4E46BC.description: Temperature can affect the state of matter of a substance.

60475FAF495845C8B1E5CDAE27C9728D.description:
Matter exists in three states: solid, liquid, gas.
  • solids have a definite shape and volume
  • liquids do not have a definite shape but have a definite volume
  • gases do not hold their shape or volume

02268BAF139C4C6187AC1271EEE1AFA6.description: Describe chemical and physical changes, including changes in states of matter

545C3918E807467D82429C21515172E8.description:
Some properties of an object are dependent on the conditions of the present surroundings in which the object exists. For example:
  • temperature - hot or cold
  • lighting - shadows, color
  • moisture - wet or dry

EC01B167701947C5AB99BCFE5C300E99.description: Objects and/or materials can be sorted or classified according to their properties.

7D69F514E1004A03B8FA68E3B36896E8.description: The material(s) an object is made up of determine some specific properties of the object (sink/float, conductivity, magnetism). Properties can be observed or measured with tools such as hand lenses, metric rulers, thermometers, balances, magnets, circuit testers, and graduated cylinders.

57BAC5E6D5724CD49F3071D2ED1D7D06.description: Measurements can be made with standard metric units and nonstandard units.
comments: Note: Exceptions to the metric system usage are found in meteorology.

F53F2F286C524031B8DC36DF8FE47FD5.description: Objects have properties that can be observed, described, and/or measured: length, width, volume, size, shape, mass or weight, temperature, texture, flexibility, reflectiveness of light.

C7C4995A95C3442498536BFF81E1AFE4.description: Matter has properties (color, hardness, odor, sound, taste, etc.) that can be observed through the senses.

59D69726447A4E01B1C8147F563505C7.description: Matter takes up space and has mass. Two objects cannot occupy the same place at the same time.

2CC82A0D5F6E484AB37DC553160B409A.description: Observe and describe properties of materials using appropriate tools

1501820C05E946DC8F4987BD3A5F3CA3.description: Matter is made up of particles whose properties determine the observable characteristics of matter and its reactivity.

77F690DBA3A6403AABCA3575640F5792.description: Extreme natural events (floods, fires, earthquakes,volcanic eruptions, hurricanes, tornadoes, and other severe storms) may have positive or negative impacts on living things.

937B81C00370436EAFDFDF38BA5F21F5.description:
Erosion and deposition result from the interaction among air, water, and land.
  • interaction between air and water breaks down earth materials
  • pieces of earth material may be moved by air, water, wind, and gravity
  • pieces of earth material will settle or deposit on land or in the water in different places
  • soil is composed of broken-down pieces of living and nonliving earth material

709178602CC84CF284D5A39E50EAE9AA.description:
Water is recycled by natural processes on Earth.
  • evaporation: changing of water (liquid) into water vapor (gas)
  • condensation: changing of water vapor (gas) into water (liquid)
  • precipitation: rain, sleet, snow, hail
  • runoff: water flowing on Earth's surface
  • groundwater: water that moves downward into the ground

02BAC1B132D84E2F81C83B2C0F991FB7.description:
Weather can be described and measured by:
  • temperature
  • wind speed and direction
  • form and amount of precipitation
  • general sky conditions (cloudy, sunny, partly cloudy)

022B81ED4BF343FC809DAD8F90999A45.description: Weather is the condition of the outside air at a particular moment.

5E2E4FBBCEE9421F88DEA76539352BFB.description: Describe the relationship among air, water, and land on Earth.

DF031C36EF5648B38C6A8E63752BA715.description: Many of the phenomena that we observe on Earth involve interactions among components of air, water, and land.

A033EEDDD2EF4A389732672E091954F9.description: The Sun and other stars appear to move in a recognizable pattern both daily and seasonally.

39CB8069BDC04BC695D67DEDC8900980.description:
Humans organize time into units based on natural motions of Earth:
  • second, minute, hour
  • week, month

6ACDA662F53E40D0A38DF68BD16B57CA.description:
Natural cycles and patterns include:
  • Earth spinning around once every 24 hours (rotation), resulting in day and night
  • Earth moving in a path around the Sun (revolution), resulting in one Earth year
  • the length of daylight and darkness varying with the seasons
  • weather changing from day to day and through the seasons
  • the appearance of the Moon changing as it moves in a path around Earth to complete a single cycle

B33B597DF00A48CBBB7772D701242880.description: The Earth and celestial phenomena can be described by principles of relative motion and perspective.

55D8F85AE6C84B918AD37C1398BD2B6B.description: Students will understand and apply scientific concepts, principles, and theories pertaining to the physical setting and living environment and recognize the historical development of ideas in science.

E16573057735491881BA98450564FCB6.description: recognize the impact of information technology on the daily life of students

C98CAD40C44E4BC699A1E342BBDF5F1C.description: demonstrate an ability to critically evaluate information and misinformation

2EE010EA146F4006B965EDAC0C9D5CC5.description: distinguish fact from fiction (presenting opinion as fact is contrary to the scientific process)

D864E38FD0E747FCBBF35F4102409D7F.description: Information technology can have positive and negative impacts on society, depending upon how it is used.

4208694D589D45629144C008B0B54F58.description: identify and report sources in oral and written communications

B6DA5E64EB084E8B8D671CA295883423.description: consult several sources of information and points of view before drawing conclusions

62A074D095EB4A0F973BE35DDC0588C4.description: use a variety of media to access scientific information

39A26A0122134726B1EAB605D72BC2AA.description: Knowledge of the impacts and limitations of information systems is essential to its effective and ethical use.

F92727A431094663AAC0BD7569DFE105.description: use information technology to link the classroom to world events

9F708557EC28454AA2CA1035E568AAAF.description: select appropriate hardware and software that aids in word processing, creating databases, telecommunications, graphing, data display, and other tasks

27C9473CECEA4E40BE512DEE54B0674F.description: use computer technology, traditional paper-based resources, and interpersonal discussions to learn, do, and share science in the classroom

BB0632F373A84072B9CA9EACA80B1434.description: Information technology is used to retrieve, process, and communicate information and as a tool to enhance learning.

CCCF2381988847DAB57898656AD16B68.description: Students will access, generate, process, and transfer information, using appropriate technologies.

307A6DC3206A4262BB359623C836CDB1.description: Analyze results and suggest how to improve the solution or model, using oral, graphic, or written formats

9238956173D74A36B8885568C33288D7.description: Perform the test and record the results, numerically and/or graphically

89A7D20412C043AF8C23AB1EF7CB060A.description: Determine a way to test the finished solution or model

9B6A723290CA49C8A0500C8D2A48FF98.description: Discuss how best to test the solution; perform the test under teacher supervision; record and portray results through numerical and graphic means; discuss orally why things worked or didn't work; and summarize results in writing, suggesting ways to make the solution better.

5291F6B0C062430B982DAD46869D6CEF.description: Build a model of the object, modifying the plan as necessary

C6CC55E6FAFD41DAAD6B3B8E353675E3.description: Create a grade-appropriate graphic or plan listing all materials needed, showing sizes of parts, indicating how things will fit together, and detailing steps for assembly

444E5594A8514F03AF4608DF3000A48C.description: Plan and build, under supervision, a model for the solution using familiar materials, processes, and hand tools.

7F8B397F7CCE4D1F93EE95DC0C58EF92.description: Select a solution consistent with given constraints and explain why it was chosen

D6CBA68BBE5D4D33878E0DA3927F1EFB.description: Develop and apply criteria to evaluate possible solutions

809C5CB792354E98A661A74FE75818A0.description: List possible solutions, applying age-appropriate math and science skills

929853DE99A2459087F2E4F56AE73E57.description: Generate ideas for possible solutions, individually and through group activity; apply age-appropriate mathematics and science skills; evaluate the ideas and determine the best solution; and explain reasons for the choices.

F7F31AF7EFC84F9BB76D9E87303977A4.description: Describe prior designs of the object

3CE31B34A9584BE9BE81A3052F43887E.description: Identify the appropriate resources to use to find out about the design of an object

6B78F254E1434CED99A5BE8B8C316745.description: Identify appropriate questions to ask about the design of an object

56860A2761DC47C299A6F8C0E1BE4517.description: Investigate prior solutions and ideas from books, magazines, family, friends, neighbors, and community members.

2BDF68707DF74A789D7393AA045874EF.description: Suggest ways the object can be made differently, fixed, or improved within given constraints

FC641534339E4EDA8CF777A69E2F43BE.description: Identify features of an object that help or hinder the performance of the object

2CAB92D5D1074290AD83CCA813C95BE1.description: Identify a simple/common object which might be improved and state the purpose of the improvement

877C9D974D5D4F72826D4C2258B5510D.description: Describe objects, imaginary or real, that might be modeled or made differently and suggest ways in which the objects can be changed, fixed, or improved.

3D1379ED75AA4982A829EB37BAE4224F.description: Engineering design is an iterative process involving modeling and optimization finding the best solution within given constraints which is used to develop technological solutions to problems within given constraints.

3826FC0B82D44B9DB9AEA6785650154D.description: State, orally and in writing, any new questions that arise from their investigation

605CF74CF543428B8C029934CA53D23D.description: State, orally and in writing, any inferences or generalizations indicated by the data, with appropriate modifications of their original prediction/explanation

7810238FE6CF423CB0590C322F6931CE.description: Adjust their explanations and understandings of objects and events based on their findings and new ideas.

C8FC90A1D93F457592916B708B369BDA.description: Explain their findings to others, and actively listen to suggestions for possible interpretations and ideas

BA5585F5E10445579A7BEE3E162822C2.description: Share their findings with others and actively seek their interpretations and ideas.

0379CB14170C4342BD128E0FE5ECEF26.description: State, orally and in writing, any inferences or generalizations indicated by the data collected

D1C2D79A76C54DDEAE8233FD46774274.description: Interpret organized observations and measurements, recognizing simple patterns, sequences, and relationships.

B3D8C43066154AF0B0D799FE3EA0B392.description: Accurately transfer data from a science journal or notes to appropriate graphic organizer

7D7FE6A1A73248F29B0D5BB54FF28504.description: Organize observations and measurements of objects and events through classification and the preparation of simple charts and tables.

5892CB267F324463836FCF582D692D87.description: The observations made while testing proposed explanations, when analyzed using conventional and invented methods, provide new insights into phenomena.

150DD3C02F6A41929EB17267D3650626.description: Use appropriate "inquiry and process skills" to collect data

367A9E5B4E424ED9A5A73A6B76434B5D.description: Carry out their plans for exploring phenomena through direct observation and through the use of simple instruments that permit measurements of quantities, such as length, mass, volume, temperature, and time.

86E3DA3CA7D34701906DD6E1DF7269C2.description: Explain the steps of a plan to others, actively listening to their suggestions for possible modification of the plan, seeking clarification and understanding of the suggestions and modifying the plan where appropriate

3E31426BF9F8464D8E5F5F1116A1F4AE.description: Share their research plans with others and revise them based on their suggestions.

61EB9794BF514913831DF0367488BF75.description: Indicate materials to be used and steps to follow to conduct the investigation and describe how data will be recorded (journal, dates and times, etc.)

BD3CA57CB6604124916FBF85B7FEE017.description: Develop written plans for exploring phenomena or for evaluating explanations guided by questions or proposed explanations they have helped formulate.

F85F84848D344362AD3977D88A36E568.description: Beyond the use of reasoning and consensus, scientific inquiry involves the testing of proposed explanations involving the use of conventional techniques and procedures and usually requiring considerable ingenuity.

81E3F54195DB4D0BBC7C0BD5B6C4B915.description: Clearly express a tentative explanation or description which can be tested

2DD5D745EAE14B38AC19C9D259D0D8F4.description: Develop relationships among observations to construct descriptions of objects and events and to form their own tentative explanations of what they have observed.

228F8D2B8EA44D3EB7175CD324DD5F75.description: Identify similarities and differences between explanations received from others or in print and personal observations or understandings

8AEBB6077E804E60B1162F302510BE85.description: Question the explanations they hear from others and read about, seeking clarification and comparing them with their own observations and understandings.

50797D6121BB444F87CC2C116F786387.description: Articulate appropriate questions based on observations

1AF0C721AC8E49589E5ECCA25ACF40A2.description: Observe and discuss objects and events and record observations

14C99377C69F4805B39A389FF0426F2D.description: Ask "why" questions in attempts to seek greater understanding concerning objects and events they have observed and heard about.

01C99EAFF2C44B48B862BDF3C7B28BEF.description: The central purpose of scientific inquiry is to develop explanations of natural phenomena in a continuing, creative process.

A1959D903F2C43939F54B5B35358AB4F.description: Use appropriate scientific tools, such as metric rulers, spring scale, pan balance, graph paper, thermometers [Fahrenheit and Celsius], graduated cylinder to solve problems about the natural world

AAAABB571CF04A38889FB0370067D796.description: Explore and solve problems generated from school, home, and community situations, using concrete objects or manipulative materials when possible.

EA2C396CE04042AFBB95B1ABD7A22790.description: Critical thinking skills are used in the solution of mathematical problems.

421E95E8D77E45918B07AE41035F9695.description: Explain verbally, graphically, or in writing patterns and relationships observed in the physical and living environment

ACE6BA381AD84E22856F434B8EBD7111.description: Explain verbally, graphically, or in writing the reasoning used to develop mathematical conclusions

4F84D7011B65485F8B2EB47290EE61AD.description: Use simple logical reasoning to develop conclusions, recognizing that patterns and relationships present in the environment assist them in reaching these conclusions.

99EC45124F704502ADDE77CEA335C218.description: Deductive and inductive reasoning are used to reach mathematical conclusions.

0FF4570AAA774B4A80A85ABEF2A10BD7.description: Apply mathematical skills to describe the natural world

DED3F5E5F541470F9075E885075D6D08.description: Select the appropriate operation to solve mathematical problems

E104E8B89210455C825D4668F6036DEB.description: Use plus, minus, greater than, less than, equal to, multiplication, and division signs

016BC4C5155E41ABAFDB14931AB1D863.description: Use special mathematical notation and symbolism to communicate in mathematics and to compare and describe quantities, express relationships, and relate mathematics to their immediate environment.

82395F28BAAC4E779BE92DA2DB2B990C.description: Abstraction and symbolic representation are used to communicate mathematically.

80C8EED63C6A4FA1B56CE5C800D8DB26.description: Students will use mathematical analysis, scientific inquiry, and engineering design, as appropriate, to pose questions, seek answers, and develop solutions.
